Charles Dickens.passage: Charles Dickens (/ˈtʃɑːrlz dɪkənz/; 12 February 1812 – 9 June 1870) was an English novelist, short-story writer and journalist. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential novelists in the English language and is frequently cited as a literary genius. He is best known for his 44 novels, most notably Great Expectations (1860), A Tale of Two Cities (1859), Oliver Twist (1838), David Copperfield (1850), and Nicholas Nickleby (1839), and for his short stories, which include The Old Curiosity Shop (1841) and A Christmas Carol (1843). He is also remembered for his novels' realism, breadth of character development, humour, and social criticism, as well as for his prolific and prodigious literary output. He wrote most of his books in the mid to late 19th century, but continued to write and publish until his death in 1870. He is regarded as one of the greatest and most influential novelists in the English language, and his works have been widely translated and adapted for stage and screen. Dickens began writing at an early age, and by 1834 had published a number of books, including the novel Oliver Twist.

William Shakespeare.passage: William Shakespeare (baptised 26 April 1564 – 23 April 1616), often referred to as Shakespeare, was an English poet, playwright, and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's pre-eminent dramatist. He is often called England's national poet, and the "Bard of Avon". Shakespeare was the King's Champion and one of the two principal playwrights of his age, the other being Christopher Marlowe. He is often called the "Bard of Avon" (a reference to his birthplace, Stratford-upon-Avon). He was born and died in Stratford-upon-Avon and spent most of his life in the town. He married at least twice and had several children. He began a legal career but retired by age 40 to pursue his calling as an actor and playwright. He achieved immense popularity in his lifetime and is often regarded as the greatest playwright who ever lived. He began a career in the theatre and by his early twenties was a successful playwright, largely through the popularity of his plays during the late 1580s and 1590s. His plays are noted for their vivid, realistic settings, rich characterisations and theatrical language, as well as for their dramatic structure and wit.

Fyodor Dostoyevsky.passage: Fyodor Dostoyevsky (;, "Fyodor Petrovich Dostoyevsky"; Russian: Фёдор Достоевский; IPA: [fjoʊˈdɐːr dɐˈstɔjɪvskij]; 9 September [O.S. 30 August] 1821 – 25 February [O.S. 6 March] 1881) was a Russian writer, philosopher and epileptic, considered to be among the greatest novelists and prose stylists in the Russian language and one of the major writers of the European novel. Dostoyevsky's literary works explore the psychology of the individual as he confronts the problems of good and evil, guilt, and faith. He wrote novels, short stories, plays, essays, literary criticism, and memoirs. His novels have been translated into every major living language and are among the most widely read books in the world. His works have had a significant impact on the course of Russian literature and on the development of the novel throughout the world. Dostoyevsky was born into a middle-class family of an Orthodox Christian priest in Moscow. He was a sensitive and intelligent child, but was afflicted by epilepsy, which caused frequent seizures that often left him unconscious.

Leo Tolstoy.passage: Leo Tolstoy (Russian: Лев Толстой, IPA: [leˈvo tolˈst�oy]; Russian: Лев Толстой (Русский: Лев Толсто́й, IPA: [leˈvo tolʂotʰoj]; 9 August 1828 – 28 January 1910) was a Russian writer, who is regarded as one of the greatest authors in world literature. He is best known for his novels War and Peace («Война и мир») and Anna Karenina («Анна Каренина»). He also published short stories, novellas, plays, essays, biographies, and religious and spiritual writings. Tolstoy was born into the nobility, but he renounced his family's wealth and lived simply, supporting his writing with his own manual labour. He travelled throughout Europe and became involved in radical movements, such as utopian socialism and anarchism. His early works were published under the pseudonym V. Odoevsky, but he achieved fame in Russia with his novels, which are considered milestones of literature in Russia and abroad.

George Orwell.passage: George Orwell (22 August 1903 – 21 January 1950) was an English writer. His novels and essays – particularly Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949) – are widely regarded as landmarks in literature, and he is regarded as one of the greatest writers of the 20th century. Orwell's works are characterised by their pessimistic yet humorous view of the future, their unflinching criticism of totalitarianism and their passionate concern with issues of political freedom and social justice. He is considered one of the greatest English prose stylists of the 20th century, and is widely regarded as one of the greatest writers of prose fiction in the English language. Born in Bengal to British colonial parents, Orwell moved to England in 1903 and was educated at Eton College and at University College, Oxford. He worked as a imperial policeman in Burma and as a sub-editor on the \"English language daily, the Tribune\", in India. In 1927, he went to Paris to work for the \"English language literary monthly, \"The Adelphi\"\", and in 1931 he returned to Paris to work for the BBC Eastern Service. In 1936, he went to Spain to report on the civil war, and in 1938 he went to Morocco as a correspondent for the \"Daily Worker\", an English communist newspaper.

Mark Twain.passage: Mark Twain (born Samuel Langhorne Clemens; November 30, 1835 – April 21, 1910) was an American author and humorist. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest American authors and one of the most influential humorists in American literature. He is best known for his novels The Adventures of Tom Sawyer (1876) and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn (1885), but he was also a master of humorous essays, short stories, and journalism. Twain wrote with great speed and produced a vast output of creative work, much of it while he was still a young man. He was born into a Missouri family with a long tradition of military service and political leadership. The family moved when he was nine years old, and he grew up in the South and West, particularly in Hannibal, Missouri, where he became familiar with the river and its characters. He became a proficient and dexterous steamboat pilot, and this experience provided much of the material for his later writing. Twain's father died when he was nine years old, and his mother struggled to raise her five children. Twain quit school after the fourth grade, but he developed a prodigious memory and a lifelong passion for books. He worked as a printer, a Mississippi riverboat pilot, and a miner, and he traveled widely, living for long periods in San Francisco, Nevada, and Hartford, Connecticut.

William Faulkner.passage: William Faulkner, born William Cuthbert Falkner, Jr. (1897–1962) was an American novelist, short-story writer, and poet. His best-known and most critically acclaimed novels are The Sound and The Fury (1929), As I Lay Dying (1930), Light in August (1932), and Absalom, Absalom! (1936). Faulkner is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential writers of the 20th century, and his works are often cited as "required reading" in college courses across the United States. He was posthumously awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1949. Faulkner was born in New Albany, Mississippi, to William Falkner (1869–1940), an Irish immigrant farmer and his wife, the former Estelle Oldham (1869–1928). Faulkner was named for his great-grandfather, William Cuthbert Falkner. His parents' marriage was unhappy; his father was an alcoholic who abused Estelle and their sons physically. Estelle died of cancer in May 1928. Faulkner was raised by his paternal grandparents, Thomas and Mary Jane Falkner, in a remote area of Jefferson County known as the "Bottom."

Jorge Luis Borges.passage: Jorge Luis Borges (English pronunciation |ˈbɔːrgs, IPA: (bɔːrʒ); Spanish: [ˈβɾɣes]; 9 June 1899 – 26 March 1986) was an Argentine writer, poet, and literary critic, known for his short stories, essays, and poetry. He was one of the most important 20th-century fiction writers in Spanish, and is often grouped together with Franz Kafka, Samuel Beckett, and Salman Rushdie as among the major post-war fiction writers of the English language. Borges' prodigious output, which includes more than 70 books and thousands of shorter pieces, made him one of the most widely translated authors in history. Borges began his writing career in the 1920s, publishing poetry, short stories, and essays in Buenos Aires-based journals. He achieved literary fame in the 1940s with the publication of the short story collection Ficciones (1944), which has been called the first modernist masterpiece in Spanish and has had significant influence on Latin American literature.

John Steinbeck.passage: John Steinbeck (July 20, 1902 – December 20, 1968) was an American author and journalist, known especially for his novels of the American West. Steinbeck's novels and short stories capture the essence of the common people and their struggles to survive in American society. Steinbeck was born in Salinas, California. His parents were both of Pennsylvania German descent. He graduated from Stanford University in 1925, where he was a member of the Phi Kappa Psi fraternity, and he received a Master of Journalism degree from the University of California, Berkeley in 1937. Steinbeck's first novel, Tortilla Flat, was published in 1935. The novel is set in Monterey, California, and is about a group of Mexican immigrants who work together to build a fishing boat. The book was not a success, and Steinbeck went through a period in which he struggled to make a living. In 1939, he married Elaine Scott, with whom he had a daughter, Thompsina, in 1940. He began work on his most famous novel, The Grapes of Wrath (1939), about the Great Depression and the Dust Bowl migration of poor Midwesterners to California. The book sold poorly when published in 1939, but was a success after the United States entered World War II.

Russia.passage: Russia (i/ˈrɐːzwʲə, rə-/ ROH-), officially the Russian Federation (russ. : Росси́я, russ. "Rossiya"), is a country in Eurasia. At, Russia is the largest country by surface (land and inland waters) and the ninth-largest by population (with 143 million people as of 2022). Russia's capital and largest city is Moscow. Moscow is one of the world's major cities, and the largest city proper on the European continent. Russia's continental territory is largely situated in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia and shares land borders with Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and China. It is bounded by the Arctic Ocean to the north, by the Pacific Ocean to the east and by the Atlantic Ocean to the west. The European westward portion of Russia, referred to as Western Russia, includes European Russia or the European Russia and also the Northwestern Federal District. Russia's climate is primarily continental, and ranges from subarctic in the north, through temperate in the centre to the subtropical Caucasus and mild-to-hot in the south. The north-east is colder and more continental than other regions, receiving less rainfall and experiencing long, very cold winters and short, cool summers, while the south-west is warmer and wetter with mild winters and long, cool summers.

Samuel Langhorne Clemens.passage: Clemens, also known as Mark Twain, was born in Florida, Missouri, on November 30, 1835, to John Marshall and Jane Lampton Clemens. His father, who had once been a slave owner, had become a newspaper editor and had served in the state legislature. Clemens was named for his mother's maiden name, and he was also known by the nickname \"Lance\". His father was a strict disciplinarian who once took Samuel and his brother Orion to task for playing in a muddy street; he also whipped them with a leather strap, a practice Clemens recalled in his autobiography. Clemens' mother was of entirely different temperament; she was kind, playful and loving. She had a talent for telling stories, which she would often do around the family's fireplace. At the age of twelve, Clemens left school and became a printer's apprentice, working fourteen-hour days. His father wanted him to become a lawyer, but Clemens instead chose a career in the burgeoning field of journalism. He worked as a printer and typesetter while he studied the craft of writing. At the age of seventeen, Clemens left home and moved to St. Louis, where he worked as a typesetter for the Hannibal Courier, a Democratic Party newspaper. He later worked for the Hannibal Journal, a Whig Party newspaper, and then for the Missouri Democrat, owned by his brother Orion.

the Phi Kappa Psi.passage: The Phi Kappa Psi fraternity was founded on December 5, 1852, at Jefferson College, a small private liberal arts college in central Pennsylvania. It is the oldest social fraternity in continuous existence in the United States. The fraternity's founding was inspired by a drinking game called "the virginals", which involved a large bowl and a yardstick. The bowl would be passed around the circle, and the yardstick placed across the top. One of the group would then take a drink every time the yardstick was tapped. The bowl and yardstick were later replaced with a bottle and a cane. The latter was used as a reminder of the fraternity's founders, who were all musicians. The fraternity's first chapter was founded at Jefferson College. The fraternity has since expanded to include over 250 chapters at colleges and universities across the United States, as well as a colony at Oxford University. The Phi Kappa Psi fraternity was the first social fraternity to be founded west of the Appalachians, and the first in the United States to be founded on the campus of a small college or university. It was also the first to adopt the Greek-letter name system, which was first used at Jefferson College. The fraternity's founding was inspired by a drinking game called the "virginals," which involved a large bowl and a yardstick.
